commit.message:
ComponentInstance unit tests (#1956)

Unit tests for `ComponentInstance.tsx`

These involve slightly complex plumbing, because they're testing the communication between `ComponentInstance` and its iframe, which all happens via `postMessage`.

This PR supersedes #1689 - that PR can be closed.

ComponentInstance unit tests (#1956)

Unit tests for `ComponentInstance.tsx`

These involve slightly complex plumbing, because they're testing the communication between `ComponentInstance` and its iframe, which all happens via `postMessage`.

This PR supersedes #1689 - that PR can be closed.

commit.message:
"streamlit-component-lib" NPM package (#1928)

Contains the new "streamlit-component-lib" npm package as a top-level directory in Streamlit.

- New code lives inside `streamlit/component-lib`. It's its own frontend project, separate from `streamlit/frontend`. It contains all the Streamlit Component bootstrap code that each component needs to use. 
- This code used to be duplicated in each project in the https://github.com/streamlit/component-template repo. This PR is essentially a big de-duplication. (There's a corresponding PR in the template repo here: https://github.com/streamlit/component-template/pull/5)
- The code will eventually get its own set of unit tests - but currently, components (and this new `streamlit-component-lib`) are thoroughly tested via our e2e test script, which runs tests against our component templates - and those templates now use this lib.
- Short instructions on how to publish updates to the npm package are in the README.md.
- The only _new_ stuff in this PR is the packaging bits and READMEs - see `component-lib/package.json` and `component-lib/tsconfig.json`.

### Annoying Apache Arrow wrinkle

There is an annoying wrinkle! `apache-arrow`, the library we use for frontend dataframe handling, has some TypeScript type declaration errors in a few places. This is a known bug (tracked here: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-8394). It's not clear to me why we didn't hit this issue when including the arrow library in our `create-react-app` component templates, but I think it may have to do with dead-code elimination. Or maybe the Babel TypeScript compiler that `create-react-app` uses doesn't have this issue? (This repo deliberately skips Babel, and just uses `tsc` directly, which makes for a much simpler packaging process.)
 
The workaround is to copy the entire set of `apache-arrow` TypeScript declarations -- all its `*.d.ts` files -- into our own declarations override directory, and modify the problematic ones to signal to TypeScript to ignore them for the purposes of typechecking. This is documented in [`component-lib/declarations/README.md`](https://github.com/streamlit/streamlit/compare/develop...tconkling:tim/ComponentNPM?expand=1#diff-354cd2595a63e8a5c389f46af76ee495), and when Arrow is fixed, we can back these changes out.

So for the purposes of PR review, just skip all the (many) files inside `declarations/apache-arrow`.

verification.payload:
tree df513072babfe412a7a47b86518d9191e46bc97c
parent 2ef50453e505f72211f8f7ce98439d7f6b02def3
author Tim Conkling <tconkling@gmail.com> 1598546239 -0700
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1598546239 -0700

"streamlit-component-lib" NPM package (#1928)

Contains the new "streamlit-component-lib" npm package as a top-level directory in Streamlit.

- New code lives inside `streamlit/component-lib`. It's its own frontend project, separate from `streamlit/frontend`. It contains all the Streamlit Component bootstrap code that each component needs to use. 
- This code used to be duplicated in each project in the https://github.com/streamlit/component-template repo. This PR is essentially a big de-duplication. (There's a corresponding PR in the template repo here: https://github.com/streamlit/component-template/pull/5)
- The code will eventually get its own set of unit tests - but currently, components (and this new `streamlit-component-lib`) are thoroughly tested via our e2e test script, which runs tests against our component templates - and those templates now use this lib.
- Short instructions on how to publish updates to the npm package are in the README.md.
- The only _new_ stuff in this PR is the packaging bits and READMEs - see `component-lib/package.json` and `component-lib/tsconfig.json`.

### Annoying Apache Arrow wrinkle

There is an annoying wrinkle! `apache-arrow`, the library we use for frontend dataframe handling, has some TypeScript type declaration errors in a few places. This is a known bug (tracked here: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-8394). It's not clear to me why we didn't hit this issue when including the arrow library in our `create-react-app` component templates, but I think it may have to do with dead-code elimination. Or maybe the Babel TypeScript compiler that `create-react-app` uses doesn't have this issue? (This repo deliberately skips Babel, and just uses `tsc` directly, which makes for a much simpler packaging process.)
 
The workaround is to copy the entire set of `apache-arrow` TypeScript declarations -- all its `*.d.ts` files -- into our own declarations override directory, and modify the problematic ones to signal to TypeScript to ignore them for the purposes of typechecking. This is documented in [`component-lib/declarations/README.md`](https://github.com/streamlit/streamlit/compare/develop...tconkling:tim/ComponentNPM?expand=1#diff-354cd2595a63e8a5c389f46af76ee495), and when Arrow is fixed, we can back these changes out.

So for the purposes of PR review, just skip all the (many) files inside `declarations/apache-arrow`.
